What happened?
Just tell me who's closer to the wall?
Get in the car.
Who is closer to the wall, Joey or me?
I said a clean break.
He's over at St. James. They had to put two pins in his arm.
How's my brother?
Fuck me?   Fuck you!
Fuck you, grease-ball!
And I'm tellin' you it ain't! Now, turn your taco-eating ass around and get the hell out of here.
I'm telling you that's my car!   And someone's gonna pay for it!
The hell it is.
No.   It's mine.
Yeah.   It's mine.
Anybody know about that car outside?
The papers for the car will arrive tomorrow.
No shit?
It's yours. A gift. A gift you could give to your brother... or anyone you owe money to as partial payment.
Yeah.
You see that car?
How?
I understand. The person who sent me wishes to help you.
I don't know what you're talking about.
I represent a person who wishes to remain anonymous, but is aware of your current financial problems with your brother.
Uh huh.
Mr. Zammito?
Cool.
I would like to thank you for your hospitality.  If you are ever in Paris here is my number.
I know where she went.
How are we going to do that?
Although a cartoon I feel he shares a universal theme: We are all searching for love. No?
Yeah, I dig him.
Oh, Pepe Le Pew. He is very funny and quite well known in France.
No thank you.
No problem, man.  Hey, you wanna hit?
I am Raymond.     Thank you for allowing us to stay here.
Glenmorangie is very good.
Glenmorangie.
J&B?
I'm more of a whiskey drinker myself.
The new Beaujolais' come out in France next week. You like wine?
He's right. Do you have any idea what Van Gogh's "Vase with twelve Sunflowers" is worth?
I say we make him pay first. After that you can do whatever you want to him.
Julien, what you're doing right now is a very normal psychological reaction to stress. You're projecting your anger onto us.
You're not helping.
It's simple. Bastaldi's moving up. He's closing down his operation and this is his way of saying thanks to all of us.
I said knock it off! Now as far as I'm concerned you two girls can bitch slap yourselves silly when this is over, but right now we've got to figure out what's going on.
Where is it, Sophie?
The money isn't here.
Wait here.
How do we know what room she's in?
What?
Holy shit.
Oh, you think?
I think we went the wrong way.
Watch this.
I'm glad you didn't get something flashy.
Feel free to correct him if you want.
He speaks about himself in the third person?
He's right. The tapes give us leverage with Bastaldi.
They killed our friend. It's personal now. Besides, if we do that, then Julien died for nothing. The tapes are the key.
I don't know.
And how do we do that?
We don't know that for sure.
It has to be at Sophie's. She didn't have time to go anywhere else before she came here.
You wanna tell him?
What does arresting us get them?

They send us to Zammito's house. The FBI is right across the street watching the whole thing, but they don't move. A crime is going down and they don't move. Why?  Because they were waiting for us to come out so they could arrest us.
How are we supposed to sleep with this noise?
I can't even hear myself think.
Zero did not put it in his bag.    He put it in yours.
You put a loaded gun in your bag and brought it through customs? How stupid is that?
-- Zero isn't interested in your life story.  Who gets killed?
Well, you know, not all Algerians speak French. It's a matter of what school you went too. Me I never really --
And you don't speak French?
Algeria.
Vincent Bastaldi is in jail.
Why?
Stick around and find out.
Who are you waiting for?
After last night I could say the same for you.
I really thought we had something special going. I can't tell you what a disappointment you've turned out to be.
It's three in the morning.    Not much else to do.
Sounds boring.
I thought I'd listen to some of the tapes. See what's so important that a mob guy has to lock it away in his safe.
What are you doing?
It's not your fault.
I'm sorry things went so wrong today.
No.
Can't sleep?
The lucky ones.
Who's gonna see it there?
I've been thinking about getting tattoo. You know, a flower or something. On my ass.
It's okay.   It was a long time ago.
Sorry.   I didn't mean to pry.
No. I got it in prison. I went in for three years. When I came out she was married to my best friend. Happy?
You got it in a bar?
I don't remember.    I was drunk.
That's how you get to know someone.       Did it hurt when you got it?
You ask a lot of questions.
It looks old.     Did you get it a long time ago?
Something like that.
Did she break your heart?
Something like that.
Casandra. Old girlfriend?
They're not nice people.
So you arranged to have the people you worked for robbed?
The art world doesn't fully appreciate my talent yet. I needed some way to pay the rent. Laurant and Vincent pay well for information.
Just lucky I guess. How'd you start working for the Bastaldi's?
So, how did you get hooked up with these guys?
It belongs to Vincent Bastaldi. He left it last time he was here. I'm sure he wouldn't mind if you used it.
No, I like the bag. It would be good for the job tonight.
You like shoes?
Take a nap.
You ever hear of jet lag?
Tonight.
When do we go?
Thanks.
I wasn't expecting this many of you. I've got a few sleeping bags you can use.
I'll get you the papers tomorrow.
Okay.    Okay.
I don't know. Sell it. It's gotta be worth something. Someone gave it to me. C'mon Frankie, I'm trying to make good here.
For me? What am I going to do with a piece of shit like this?
It's for you.
Oh really? Thanks. I thought it was a sewing machine. What the hell is it doing here?
A car.
What's this?

What are you nuts? A debt is a debt. I was thinking I'd throw a little extra work your way. You know, you come down to the club, make espresso for the boys... wash their cars... run some errands... things like that.
You gonna forget about the money I owe you?
Yeah. I mean, you are my brother and... well I should have found another way of expressing my disappointment. So, I've decided to make it up to you.
A little?
I don't want anything. I just wanted to say... that I may have... overreacted a little the other day.
Yeah. I'm going home today.    What do you want, Frankie?
Yeah. I mean besides that.    They treating you all right? Food okay?
You broke my arm. How the hell do you think I'm doin'?
So, I just come by to see how you're doin'?
That's good.    That's what a stand-up guy does.
She doesn't know. She thinks I fell down the stairs.
She seems pleasant enough.
That's why we're only breaking one arm.
Jesus, Frankie, I'm your brother!
-- Shut up! Don't you try to make me feel bad about this. You knew what would happen to you if you didn't pay. This is on your head, not mine.  Break his arm.
Frankie, I --
Well, Li Mu Bai can do it.
I didn't have the heart.
She's crazy.  You should have killed her.
I'll go and make up his room!
Li Mu Bai is coming to stay the night.
Much better.  You've been gone so long.
How's the arm?  Still sore?
You're back!
Pardon me, but I doubt you can handle her.  My wife was quite a martial arts expert.  Jade Fox killed her.  So you see, this is personal.  Leave her to me.
Then leave her to me.
Yes.
This Jade Fox is a woman?

I'm looking for someone.  Jade Fox. I'm a police inspector from Shaan Xi, Gen Su district.  Jade Fox is a master criminal.  I hear she infiltrated the Yus.  She must have come with them when they transferred here.  But with Yu's reputation, I can't just go in and accuse her.
Why were you spying on the Yus?
I don't care about your sword.
Wait!  I'm a friend!
Who are you?
That's a risk I'm willing to take. Deep down, you're good.  Even Jade Fox couldn't corrupt you.
And if I use them to kill you?
I've always wanted a disciple worthy of Wudan's secrets.
Why do you want to teach me?
Why should I?  You need practice. I can teach you to fight with the Green Destiny, but first you must learn to hold it in stillness.
Go ahead.
Real sharpness comes without effort.
On guard!
Then tell me where Jade Fox is.
Stop talking like a monk!  Just fight!
Like most things, I am nothing. It's the same for this sword.  All of it is simply a state of mind.
Do you think you are a real master?
What's it to you?
Where's your master?
I do as I please.
Isn't it a bit too late to be out? You've brought me the sword?
Let's go!
Tell me, who is your master?
I'm just playing around.
My name is Li Mu Bai.  The Green Destiny is mine.  Jade Fox can't be your master.  Where did you learn that "Xuan Piu" move?
What's it to you?
Who are you?  Why is the Green Destiny in your possession?
Believe me, I've a lesson or two left to teach you!

Master... I started learning from you in secret when I was 10.  You enchanted me with the world of Giang Hu.  But once I realized I could surpass you, I became so frightened!  Everything fell apart. I had no one to guide me, no one to learn from.
If I hadn't seen you fight with Li Mu Bai, I'd still be ignorant of all you've hidden from me.
You wouldn't have understood, even if I had tried to explain.  You know... you've gone as far as you can go.  I hid my skills so as not to hurt you.
I studied the diagrams.  But you hid the details!
You think you've been teaching me all these years from the manual? You couldn't even decipher the symbols!
Yes, you do!  You are still my disciple.
I owe you nothing.
It's the Giang Hu fighter lifestyle... kill or be killed. Exciting, isn't it?
Shut up!
Wherever we want.  We'll get rid of anyone in our way.  Even your father.
That was just for fun.  How can I leave?  Where would I go?
You're already a thief.
I'll never live as a thief!

They wouldn't have found me if you hadn't stolen the sword.  Like a little girl, you thought stealing would be fun?  You, too, are responsible for that death.  Come with me.  You don't want to waste your life as the wife of some bureaucrat.  Denied your talent... As a master and disciple we will rule.
Why are you still here?  You killed a policeman.  You should leave! You'll bring ruin on my whole family.
You're home late... or should I say early?
He is my defeated foe!
Are you related to Li Mu Bai?
So what if I don't?
You don't seem to understand.
Don't bother.
In that case, perhaps we could be of assistance.
Long.
Hello.  What is your name?
I have a guest.
This spells trouble.
Autumn is coming.  I'll shut the windows for you.
It will be just the same.  Enough! I'm tired.
Go to bed then.  Miss has grown up, and is getting married soon.  God knows what the future will bring.
I'm tired now.
Don't invite danger into your father's house.
I'll socialize with whomever I please.
She's one of those.  Your mother would not want you consorting with her kind.
Do you know her?
I heard you met Shu Lien today.
Put them down.
I've made you silk pajamas.  Do you want to change into them?
Please sit.
Spare your energy.  I'll be back!
Take my horse and go to the compound. Give this to Mrs. Wu.  She'll help you.  Hurry!
She used Purple Yin... Purple Yin poison.  It goes straight to the heart.
You can't die!  Tell us what poison you used!  You can't die!  Tell us the antidote!  You can't let Li Mu Bai die!
Don't be a sore loser.  Go ahead. Take your pick.  I'll wait.  Go ahead.
Without the Green Destiny, you are nothing.
Come and get it if you can.
Don't touch it!  That's Li Mu Bai's sword.
What do I care?  You were never a real friend anyway.  But I wonder, how long could you last as my enemy?

How dare you accuse us?  I always knew you had stolen the sword! I've done nothing but protect you and your family.  And you're repaid me with nothing but contempt.  Li Mu Bai himself spared you, and all you do is insult him.  We wanted some peace and you've ruined it all! You're no sister of mine!
You're working together to set me up!  I'm leaving!
Li Mu Bai has made arrangements. He sent him to Wudan Mountain.
Where is he now?
He really loves you.  Come back to Peking with me.  We'll find a solution.
You know about Lo?
Go back to them first.  Then you can decide about Lo.
They forced me to marry!

Look at the trouble you've caused. Now you know what Giang Hu life is really like.  If you think of me as your sister, let me give you some sisterly advice.  You can run from marriage, but not your parents.
You, sister...
I was just passing by and wondered how you were.
I'll give them to you.
I'm just borrowing some clean clothes.  I'm not staying.
Here you must be in proper attire.
Yes, from the West.  He went undercover and and followed her here,
You say she killed a policeman?
Then as a sister, let me wish you happiness in your marriage.
Don't distance us.  From now on, let's be like sisters.
I am not an aristocrat, as you are... but I must still respect a woman's duties.
Too bad for Meng, but it's not your fault, or Li Mu Bai's.

His name was Meng Si Zhao.  He was a brother to Li Mu Bai by oath. One day, while in battle, he was killed by the sword of Li Mu Bai's enemy.  After, Li Mu Bai and I went through a lot together.  Our feelings for each other grew stronger.  But how could we dishonor Meng's memory?  So the freedom you talk about, I too desire it.  But I have never tasted it.
No, really?
Yes.  Did you know I was once engaged to be married?
About you and Li Mu Bai?
Do you think so?  Let me tell you a story.

Am I?  I wish I were like the heroes in the books I read.  Like you and Li Mu Bai.  I guess I'm happy to be marrying.  But to be free to live my own life, to choose whom I love... That is true happiness.
You are fornuate to marry into such a noble family.
I'm hardly doing a thing.  The less I think of it the better.  My parents are arranging everything. The Gous are a very powerful family. My marrying one will be good for my father's career.
Thank you for seeing me.  I hear your wedding day is near.  You must be overwhelmed by the preparations.
Please.
Maybe it is.  I wouldn't know.
You write gracefully.  Calligraphy is so similar to fencing.
I'll write your name.  Just for fun.
You're doing calligraphy?
I'm bored.
How so?
I've missed you.
You're probably right.
No!  You couldn't roam around freely if you were.
What do you think?
You're not married, are you?
So I heard.  Congratulations.  It's the most important step in a woman's life, isn't it?
You know what I mean.  I'm getting married soon, but I haven't lived the life I want.
Sure.  No place to bathe for days, sleeping in flea-infested beds... They tell you all about that in those books?
But you're just like the characters in the stories.
Writers wouldn't sell many books if they told how it really is.
I've read all about people like you. Roaming wild, beating up anyone who gets in your way!
Fighters have rules too: friendship, trust, integrity... Without rules, we wouldn't survive for long.
It must be exciting to be a fighter, to be totally free!
Really?
Yes, I am.  But I prefer the machete.  Certain moves, however, call for a sword.
You're a sword fighter too?
You're too young to understand.
Li Mu Bai!  The famous warrior? Why would he give his sword to Sir Te?
My friend Li Mu Bai.  He's given it to Sir Te as a gift.
Exquisite!  You said it belongs to...
Beautiful but dangerous.  Once you see it tainted with blood, its beauty is hard to admire.  It's 400 years old.
But I have had much practice.  As a child in the West, a platoon lived with us.  They'd let me play with their weapons.  The scabbard is so beautiful.
The handle is heavy.  And the blade is no ordinary metal.  Still, the sword is the lightest of weapons. You're just not used to handling it.
It's heavy for such a thin piece of metal!
All right.  Hurry.  I will hold on as long as I can.
The antidote exists.  She taught it to me.  The formula is simple, but it takes time to prepare.  Trust me. As you have helped me, let me help you.
Then you have no use for the sword.
Never!
Kneel!
Give it back!
All right.  If you can take back the sword in three moves, I'll go with you.
What I've always wanted, to teach you.
What do you want?
Only the sword will settle this.
Let's end this here.
Not another lecture!  On guard!
Stop it!  You don't deserve the Green Destiny.
Make a wish, Lo.
"A faithful heart makes wishes come true."
Do you remember the legend of the young man?
Don't ever come back.
Jen...
Go.
If you don't, I'll come after you. And I won't let you off so easy.
I will.
Keep it safe.  Return it to me when we are together again.

You must decide.  You might get tired of this life.  You might begin to miss your family.  If it were our daughter, we'd look for her too.  She would miss us.  Jen... I want you to be mine forever.  I will make my mark on the world.  I will earn your parents' respect. We have a legend.  Anyone who dares to jump from the mountain, God will grant his wish.  Long ago, a young man's parents were ill, so he jumped.  He didn't die.  He wasn't even hurt.  He floated away, far away, never to return.  He knew his wish had come true.  If you believe, it will happen.  The elders say, "A faithful heart makes wishes come true."
Don't send me back!
It is trouble for me.
Let them look.
Your father's men are still looking for you.  They're still out there, circling closer.
I am a man.  And now I've found the brightest star of all.
So you're still that little boy looking for shooting stars.

Out here, you always fight for survival.  You have to be part of a gang to stand a chance.  Slowly, your gang becomes your family.  All that Dark Cloud stuff is just to scare people and make my life easier.
And so, the little boy became a fearsome bandit.  He couldn't find the stars, so he stole my comb.

When I was a boy, one night, I saw a thousand shooting stars.  I thought, where did they all go? I'm an orphan.  I used to look for stars alone.  I thought if I rode to the other end of the desert, I'd find them.  I've been riding in the desert ever since.
Give it back.
I don't take orders from anyone.
Give me back my comb.
I'm sorry... I guessed wrong.  I though you were a Han.
By the way, I'm a real Manchurian.
Not true.  I can use it to pick fleas from my horse.
It's mine.  It means a lot to me. A barbarian like you wouldn't understand.
No more hitting on the head!  All this trouble for a comb?
Still in a bad mood?  At least you're speaking.  What's your name?
You coward!
You've got quite a temper.  It's better this way.
My comb!
Well, there used to be!  What's your name?  I'm Lo.  The Hans call me Dark Cloud.  I'm not that tall or big, but I'm quick as lightning.
You're tired.  You need rest.  Your horse needs water.  There's a creek up here.
Give it back!
Let's stop a moment.

With all the traffic on your rooftop these days... it took me a while to get in here.  I can't wait any longer.  I was wrong to let you go.  Come back with me.  You'll be happy in the desert.  You'll be free there.
You shouldn't have come.
Jen!
Lo?

I've already wasted my whole life. I want to tell you with my last breath... I have always loved you. I would rather be a ghost, drifting by your side... as a condemned soul... than enter heaven without you.  Because of your love... I will never be a lonely spirit.
Use it to meditate.  Free yourself from this world as you have been taught.  Let your soul rise to eternity with your last breath.  Do not waste it... for me.
My life is departing.  I've only one breath left.
Save your strength.
Shu Lien...
Mu Bai, hold on.  Give me some hope...
That can't be!  Everything has an antithesis!  Why not this?
My blood will soon reverse its flow. It's the same poison she used to kill my master.  There is no antidote.
We followed Jade Fox.
Jade Fox drugged her.  How did you get here?
What happened?
Not a bad idea.  Tonight we'll get a good night's sleep at headquarters.
I'll look around and catch up later.
What about you?
We're close to your headquarters. Go home and check in.
You're right, but I don't know what to do.  I want to be with you... just like this.  It gives me a sense of peace.
To repress one's feelings only makes them stronger.
Giang Hu is a world of tigers and dragons, full of corruption... I tried sincerely to give it up but I have brought us only trouble.
Your hand, rough and callused from machete practice... All this time, I've never had the courage to touch it.
Not everything is an illusion.  My hand... wasn't that real?
Shu Lien... The things we touch have no permanence.  My master would say... there is nothing we can hold on to in this world.  Only by letting go can we truly possess what is real.
All right.  I'll write you an introduction.  Take it to Wudan. Wait there for news from me.
Don't you want to see her again.
She's out there, but I doubt she'll show herself.  We'll keep our eyes open.  Sooner or later, she'll come for the girl.
You think Jade Fox will show up?
Just be patient with me, Shu Lien.
I wish there were something more I could do to help you.
I thought by giving away the sword, I could escape the Giang Hu world. But the cycle of bloodshed continues.
It's not our affair.  Even if Wudan accepts her, her husband might object.
For her, they might make an exception.  If not, I'm afraid she'll become a poisoned dragon.
But Wudan does not accept women.
That's not for her.  She should come to Wudan and become a disciple.
She's an aristocrat's daughter. She's not one of us.  In any case, it will all be over soon.  You'll kill Fox, and she'll marry.
She needs direction... and training.
I knew she would intrigue you.
You did your job well.  But, this girl... I saw her last night.
My job was to get the sword back, without embarassing anyone.  I wasn't about to ruin her life, or her father's.
True.  But I must borrow it for one last mission.  Jade Fox must die at its edge.  Did you know what you were hiding when you covered for that girl?
But it's not your sword anymore. You gave it to Sir Te.
I admit, getting it back makes me realize how much I'd missed it.
Well, we had talked...
Then, why did you come?
I don't know it was stolen until I got here.
What do you mean?  Didn't you come back here for it?
That's not what I meant.  I don't care about the sword.
No, I'd already sent them home. You can blame me for losing the sword, but please trust that I'll get it back soon using my own methods.
But your men are watching over Yu's compund?
No, not yet...
Have you questioned him yet?
It was Bo, Sir Te's man.  I hear he followed the thief to the Yus'.
It says Jade Fox is hiding at Yu's. On the night of the theft there was a brawl near Yu's.  Were you involved?
No.
Did you see who posted it?
Be careful.  Sir Te requires discretion.  Official business is difficult enough.  Don't let personal feelings make it worse. And I don't know... even this poster... could be some sort of trap.
So I shall avenge my master's death after all.
Is there any place safer than under the nose of Governor Yu?
I didn't think she'd dare come back to Peking!
You always suspected she'd fled to the West.
Jade Fox?  Impossible.
What have you discovered?
But something is going on at the Yu household.
Sir Te believes it's a ploy cast suspicion on Governor Yu.
Perhaps.
Join me once you have finished.  I can wait for you in Peking.
First I must visit my master's grave.  It's been many years since Jade Fox murdered him.  I have yet to avenge his death.  And yet I'm thinking of quitting.  I must pray for his forgiveness.
Come with me to Peking.  You can give the sword to Sir Te yourself. It'll be just like old times.
So what will you do now?
It's time for me to leave it behind.
You use it justly, you're worthy of it.
Too many men have died at its edge. It only looks pure because blood washes so easily from its blade.
I don't understand.  How can you part with it?  It has always been with you.
I am.  He has always been our greatest protector.
The Green Destiny Sword?  You're giving it to Sir Te?
Perhaps I could ask you to deliver something to Sir Te for me.
We're preparing a convoy for a delivery to Peking.
Something I can't let go of.  You are leaving soon?
What was it?

No.  I didn't feel the bliss of enlightenment.  Instead... I was surrounded by an endless sorrow.  I couldn't bear it.  I broke off my meditation.  I couldn't go on. There was something... pulling me back.
You were enlightened?
During my meditation training... I came to a place of deep silence... I was surrounded by light... Time and space disappeared.  I had come to a place my master had never told me about.
Why?  You're a Wudan fighter. Training is everything.
I left the training early.
The mountain must be so peaceful... I envy you.  My work keeps me so busy, I hardly get any rest.
Yes.
Monk Zheng said you were at Wudan Mountain.  He said you were practicing deep meditation.
Fine.
Good.  And how are you?
It has.  How's business?
Mu Bai...It's been too long.
I doubt it.  This thief... it very unusual...
Maybe the murderer and the thief are one and the same.
A female criminal!  Now that's news!
Yes.  The very killer of Li Mu Bai's own master.  Last night, she killed a policeman who had tracked her down.
A murderer?
No mercy will be shown toward the murderer who turned up in Peking.
But don't be too lenient.
Sir Te knows that even well-meaning people can make mistakes... that can bring ruin to themselves and their families.
That's good.  Sometimes the help can't keep their hands to themselves. It's very embarassing.
We know who stole the missing item. If the thief returns it, I'm sure Sir Te will pursue the matter no further.
I heard Sir Te lost something.  And now Madame Te's not feeling well...
I'm sorry she's not feeling well enough to receive you today.
Madam Te is certainly spoiling us with these wedding gifts.  She's being so considerate.
Father!  Let me avenge my mother's death.
If you surrender now, you'll suffer less.  But if you resist, I won't stop until you're dead.
"We'll settle this at midnight on Yellow Hill."  Good, the fox is out of her hole.
What does it say?
They're gone.
Father!
You're mistaken.  We're just street performers.  We were rehearsing.
We must avenge mother!
It's Jade Fox!
The best way to trap a fox is through her cubs.
What do you have in mind?
Sir Te, can you find some excuse to invite Madam Yu and her daughter?
This is a delicate matter.
We must be careful.  Governor Yu is a court official, and in charge of security.  Any disturbance will cast suspicion on him.  It might get Sir Te in trouble.
Then someone's trying to set him up. We should inform Li Mu Bai.
But the sword could be in his compound.
Yes, though I doubt he's involved in this.
Has Governor Yu ever seen the sword?
When it comes to emotions, even great heroes can be idiots.  Tell me if Li Mu Bai is not more open the next time you see him.  I'll give him an earful!
I beg your pardon.  Li Mu Bai and I aren't cowards.

Don't be coy.  I've always known about your feelings for each other. All these years, it's a shame... neither of you is brave enough to admit the truth to the other. You're both wasting precious time.
I don't know...
Li Mu Bai giving up his sword and his warrior days... maybe he's trying to tell you something?
Please, Sir Te, what is it?

Please do not be such a stranger. You'll stay the night as my guest. Now, Shu Lien... tell me something. And forgive me for prying.  Your father was a great friend to me, and I think of you as my own daughter.
You've always been so good to Li Mu Bai and me.  Please accept our thanks.

The purpose of decapitation is to preserve as much...food...as possible. The purpose for feeding is to keep the beasts on our side. The fact that they can be taught to clean up our garbage or to fire a gun is a convenient side benefit, not the primary goal. The primary goal is to keep ourselves from becoming their supper. Keep them fed and they behave. Keep them hungry and they revert back to being the animals that they have always been. You saw them in there.

They are brutes without feeling. Though I admit that I've requested cremation for myself. Burial is an archaic tradition, even more ridiculous now than it ever was. To say nothing of the...spacing problem...on a small island like this.

Belle --
No, thank you -- what's your name?
You're not resting well, are you? I know -- it's that music.  You need your sleep. Is there anything else you want?
I've brought you something to keep you warm, Mrs. Stone --
Jabez -- ?
No, siree, it didn't. And it won't -- no matter what happens -- just as long as the folks at the fair believe in freedom and Union. So --  Giddyap, Constitution -- and let's keep going, Mr. Stone.
But it didn't stop. I know it didn't stop. Granny told me it didn't.

You're wrong, Mr. Stone. There are people who live and die without e'er seeing it. They can't see the country for the money in their pockets -- And some think their state's the country, or the way they live is the country, and they're willing to split the country because of that. Well, I hope you'll meet all those, when you're grown. You'll meet the fire-eaters and the Circassian beauties -- that's part of the fair, to be sure. But if we'd had to depend on them, in a permanent way, the country would have stopped at the Allegheny mountains.
Anybody can see that.

Well -- it's high and it's wide and it goes a long way and there is a wind blowing through it and a blue roof over it -- it's the hills up here and the rivers running south and the new States growing in the West.
What's that, sir?
Maybe you can, sometime, Daniel. I'm a farmer, you know, and like to show my farm -- but the thing I'd like to show you most, you'll have to see for yourself.
Golly -- I'd like to see all your horses!

No, Daniel -- they are not race horses. They are good old friends of mine. I call 'em Constitution and Bill of Rights, the most dependable pair for long journeys. I've got one called Missouri Compromise, too, and then there's a Supreme Court -- fine, dignified horse, though you do have to push him now and then.
Make them go faster, Mr.... ?
It does hurt! And don't you do it again.
Why? It don't hurt.
Daniel! Don't ever let me catch you doing that again!
And serve him right!
Well, I thought he'd come in the middle.
And what about Daniel Webster?
I think I'd like to begin with the fire-eater --
A varied list of attractions. And which would you like to see first, Dan'l?
'N Daniel Webster will be there.
Young man -- you got me there.
And two unpara-- unparalleled Cir-cass-ian beauties? What is that?
Guess there will, if it says so.
No -- but I can hardly wait -- Mister -- tell me, will there really be --  -- a man that eats fire?
It hasn't opened yet?
Gee -- that Fair --
All right, Daniel. Jump in.
Well, I wouldn't mind.  But my name's Daniel Stone.
Hello, Colonel! Want a lift?
All right, darling.
I don't want to be up there all alone, Mama.... I want to be with you.
Daniel! ... You must go to sleep.
Mama!
No, no, I don't want to go to bed. I want to be here for the party.
Daniel, you ought to be in bed.
Daniel! ...  I've stood just about as much as I can bear!
No! No! I won't.
Daniel give me that beanshooter!
It's mine, Ma! Pa made it for me -- and I'm not going to give it to anyone!
Yes, you did, Daniel! I saw it from the window. And then to lie about it! Give me that beanshooter, Daniel!
Not me!
I see you! Riding pretty high, ain't you? Look out you don't fall off.
Grandma, look at me!
I did not, Grandma.
Lan's to goodness, what happened to that hen? Did you use that beanshooter again?
That's just too bad --
But I like the new one better.
Move? -- We are not going to move -- the old one is good enough for us.
Granny, when do we move to the new house?

Now don't you worry about that. You just leave it all to me. We won't talk business now ... just bear this in mind ... I'm not the man to get rich on other people's hard luck.... No, sir... not me! ...
Say ... about the interest ...
Thanks, Jabez -- I really wouldn't need very much ... if you could let me have some seed to start off with enough for spring planting ...
Not at all, Hank ... not at all. Glad to help you.
Don't I? ... Say, that's mighty white of you, Jabez.
Oh -- you don't have to go to Miser Stevens while I'm around.
Yes, but what does a farmer do if he don't want to get roped in some more by them loan sharks?
I don't know -- don't seem much of an idea to me.
Well -- here's how it is ...Tom Sharp, Eli Higgins and a couple of others been talking to me about -- that new sort of organization -- grange they call it. What you think about it?
Why, of course, Hank -- I've always got time for a neighbor. What's on your mind?
Kin you spare a moment for me Jabez?
Howdy, Hank.
Howdy, Jabez.
We'll be mighty glad to have you with us.
Why, thank you, Tom. I was going to ask you if you thought I could.
Jabez -- will you join our Grange now?
I'll look out for myself! ... Now go away -- leave me alone.
Well -- we don't mean to force you, Jabez Stone -- but -- it's only for your own good.
That farmers' association -- we were talking about the other day.
What Grange?
Howdy, Mr. Stone. We've come round to ask you if you made up your mind to join the Grange?
What do you want?
Black Dan'l?
Why not! There's a bill up in Congress to give us a uniform law of bankruptcy. Daniel Webster is fighting for it right now--
I am just thinkin' -- now they mightn't like the idea down in Washington.
That's fair enough, Jabez. Man's got a right to mull things over. We'll drive round again, week or so.
Sure does. But I'll have to sleep on it a couple of nights.
Yes, it's the debt and the lien and the mortgage that eats up the farmer!
Sure am.
Are you one of old Stevens' customers too?
Too bad it didn't happen to Miser Stevens.
Loan shark -- hey?
Belle --
Belle.
Never mind. What's your name?
But she is -- I've taken her place. Don't you remember -- you wrote me a letter. Mrs. Stone was too ill.
She couldn't be gone!
No. She's gone.
You're not -- Dorothy.
Stevens -- what's all this leading up to? You know something. Come on! Out with it -- you know something about me!
I do -- and I think you should too.
Huh? -- What's that?  Well -- what about it? Who cares, anyhow?
What if one hasn't a soul any more? What of that?
All right -- so it's buried with you!
Don't say that -- I know it is --
Why do you fret about something that isn't there?
But what becomes of our souls?
Are you plumb crazy, man! What do you think happens? We're buried -- that's all.
-- of what happens after we die!
Afraid ... of what?
You are afraid!
What's the matter with you?
Well -- it seems to me -- I remember when you paid me--
Almost seven.  No -- no, he's not seven yet I am sure --
What a fine boy you have, Jabez. How old is he now?
Now run along, Daniel.
I dunno -- I can't figure it out. I've invited them all. Why don't they come?
Where's everybody?
No, you're not.
Good evening -- I'm sorry, Jabez -- I'm a little late.
Some other time, Stevens.
Yes, I wanted to get here before the others.... I want to talk to you alone.
Hello, Stevens ... you're early today.
Mornin', Jabez ...
Doesn't satisfy, eh? Well -- that's too bad....
Real! Sheriff, you are a witness that this money is paid me voluntarily, and while it does not satisfy the mortgage, it has become my property.
You know -- some folks are just lucky. Others pick gold right out of the air.  Like that!
I'd like to know where you'd get it....
-- in gold.
No, Stone!
I barely managed to scrape up a bit for you. I thought if I made a kind of part payment --
Well, Stone -- have you got the money?
Stevens!
Gentlemen, the prosecution rests.
You know darn well it is.
But, Mr. Stone, I am hardly to blame for the pricking of your wholly unnecessary conscience.  Is this your signature?
Yes -- yes, I am the richest man -- too rich. I can't think of anything but money. That's the trouble with me.
That is highly irrelevant to this case, Your Honor.
Yes, I did -- but you tricked me into signing it! You told me my soul was nothing ... that I could forget all about a soul, in exchange for money. That was a lie, a lie, a lie.
Jabez Stone -- did you or did you not sign this document?
Never!
Are you willing to give me your son in exchange for an extension of our contract?
About what?
Well now, Mr. Stone, did you make up your mind?
Come, come, Mr. Stone, you are a little upset. It's not fair to bargain with you now. -- I'll give you until midnight, Mr. Stone, but not one minute more. Ah, then you'll come with me indeed.
No! No! No! Not him -- not my son -- I'd rather go with you -- right now.
I'm afraid that's hardly the sort of security I was thinking of --  You see -- there is that promising little fellow, your son ...
Anything -- anything. -- You can have it all back -- that money -- the new house -- my farm -- the whole caboodle!
Suddenly you seem quite desperate, Mr. Stone --  -- You know I'm a good-natured man. I'm always open to reason. With a little security -- I might--
Not now! Not now!  -- Let me make up -- let me make up.
Oh no, you violated clause five of our contract and I could collect right now, if I chose.
I have still a year -- a year to make up for everything.
What a headstrong fellow! Well -- I guess you're quite prepared to suffer the consequences.
I'm through with you.
Trying to break our contract again, Mr. Stone?
My time isn't up yet.

Small? Oh, I see what you mean. Why, they vary.  Now a man like Daniel Webster, if I ever get hold of him, I'd have to build a special box for him and even at that, I imagine, the wing spread would be astonishing.  In your case --
Are they all as -- small -- as that?
He was --
He ain't dead -- he's dancing in there.
.... Miser Stevens' soul, Mr. Stone. Yes -- I am sorry for the disturbance.
Just a minute, neighbor Stone. I promised you money and all that money can buy. I don't recall any other obligations. But let's look at the contract.
You promised me prosperity, happiness, love, money, friendship --
Why, Mr. Stone, you look so worried. Can I be of any service?
Oh, certainly. I shan't even come to the christening -- it would be tactless and in wretched bad taste.  But I may send a friend of mine -- just for old sake's sake. Yes, I might do that.
Leave your tongue off of that!
But you should, now that you are becoming a father.
I don't care.
Oh come, Neighbor Stone. I wouldn't cut that tree if I were you. It means a breach of contract.
Look here now--
Good evening, Neighbor Stone.
1840. Well, that'll take us to the seventh day of April in 1847.
The seventh day of April --
Yes, indeed. But not now. Not for seven years. Oh, I almost forgot -- what is the date?
Well, I'll be --
Excellent. A firm, fair signature. One that will last till doomsday.  My dear Neighbor Stone, I congratulate you! You're going to be the richest man in New Hampshire!
A pin, Neighbor Stone! I'm afraid, you'll have to prick your finger -- but what's a little pain to a lucky man?
No, no! Give it to me!

Well, why should that worry you. A soul -- a soul is nothing. Can you see it, smell it, touch it? -- No! -- Think of it -- this soul -- your soul -- a nothing, against seven whole years of good luck! You will have money and all that money can buy. Upon my word, Neighbor Stone, if it weren't for my firm's reputation for generous dealing--
What does it mean here -- about my soul?

That's right, Mr. Stone -- there is --  -- just one little formality. I'd like your signature here -- see. And when it's done -- it's done for seven years.  It's our usual form. Of course -- we may be able to take up the question of a renewal in due time.
It's mine?
Yes, of course, people forgot -- or the men who knew about it died, you know how these things happen.
Yes, why shouldn't it?
Oh, you know the old story -- the Hessian wagon train that was ambushed on the way to Saratoga. Some of the gold has been buried under your barn!
Where did it come from?

A clever man like yourself -- he can find money anywhere. Money to pay his bills -- money for his wife and his children -- money to be a rich man. All he needs is a friend to point it out to him.  Like that!
Well, now, Mister, that sounds all right. But--

Of course. Why man, you have one of the richest farms in the county.  You just go about it the wrong way -- so many men do. Hard work -- well, that's all right for people who don't know how to do anything else. It's all right for people who aren't lucky -- but once you're lucky -- you don't work for other people. You make them work for you.
Opportunities?
You've had a lot of bad luck these days. And yet -- it's all so unnecessary. When I think of your opportunities --
You can't say that to me! I'm New Hampshire. If I say I called you, I did.  I guess I did.
Do you deny that you called me? I've known people in other States who went back on their word. But I didn't expect it in New Hampshire.
Breakfast ... Ah! ... Come along friends, Ma Stone's a cook this side of heaven.
Ma says breakfast's ready, Mr. Webster!
I know -- that was mighty queer Medford -- knew it the minute I tasted it. But it takes more than that to down Daniel Webster.
Well, I --
You were worried, Jabez, weren't you?
Oh, come, man, come. Just because you've sold your soul to the devil that needn't make you a teetotaler.
There's no joy in it for me.
There's nothing like it. I saw an inchworm take a drop of it once, and he stood right up on his hind legs and bit a bee. Come -- try a nip!
Then I'll just christen the jug, with your permission, Stone. Somehow or other, waiting's wonderfully shorter with a jug.
Not long -- now.
They make plucky women in New England.  H'm ... how long have we to wait?
Yes -- at midnight.
I see. And this is where he'd like to collect, too.
Yes, Mr. Webster -- it was here where it all began.
It's here you said that you closed the deal with him?

It's your fault! You brought Daniel Webster here -- just to try to make a fool of me! You played the sneak behind my back -- made up all sorts of lies against me! You can get yourself out of my home -- go back to the other house -- that old place, where you belong -- I don't want to -- to talk to you again!
No -- you haven't time -- You haven't time for your mother, or your wife, or your child.
I -- I don't know what you're talking about! I -- I haven't time to listen to all this --

I'm sorry you can't see that, I know you could once -- you made a little speech once, that I'll always remember and I know the others do too --  They remember and they see how you have changed. That's why they didn't want to come tonight to you, Jabez -- you're as blind as a Burma bat, with your gold pot! Mind you, it's not the money, I've been talking about, it's what you make of it.
They'd have a good neighbor, Jabez -- and that's worth much more than anything else -- much, much more!
Contracts? -- Yes, they have contracts with me -- lots of 'em -- but -- but that's all right. Without me and my money, they wouldn't have anything.
You, Jabez Stone -- you and a lot of poor farmers, hereabouts -- good men of the earth who are in trouble because of you. Or -- am I wrong about those contracts, Mr. Stone?
What -- what's on your mind?

That's just fine, Neighbor Stone -- but -- I have to be pretty careful of my seats of honor -- where I sit, I mean. You see, the whole country sort of has its eye on me, Jabez -- anybody in public life has that difficulty -- even you, Jabez. They watch us carefully, our neighbors and our enemies, and they see much more than we think they do -- and understand much more. My friends all like to think that I've got the good of mankind always at heart, and I've got to make sure that those I deal with have the good of mankind always at heart, too. Do you know what I'm talking about, Jabez?
Well -- Mr. Webster! This is a great day for me. Come on in, sir. I want you to take the seat of honor and meet all my guests!
Well -- I'll be -- if it isn't little Mary Sampson from Franklin.
Mr. Webster -- I'd like you to meet my wife, Mary.
Eloquent speech, Neighbor Stone -- couldn't have done better myself --  -- under the circumstances.  Thank you.
Thanks, Mr. Webster!  To the champion of the whole United States -- Dan'l Webster!
Here's a man who knows what's good for Dan'l Webster! Medford rum! Ah, a breath of the Promised Land!  To the champion of the Iron Horseshoe, Jabez Stone!
Not at all, lad -- not at all.  For a good game of horseshoes I would always sacrifice fame and acclaim.
Seems like it's my fault, Mr. Webster.
I don't seem to be so very popular after all -- in Cross Corners.
Thank you, Mr. Webster.
You win. Will you ride to the village with me, Mr. Stone?
Ten throws it is.
Ten throws -- Mr. Webster?
Shake!
5000 -- that's just what I owe you.
How much?
Why not -- ?
Oh yes -- I am -- want to bet?
You are not so sure that he'll come.
That's fine. Now you can tell people all about the house, but don't mention Webster.
Well -- yes --
Now, Squire, you're not going to let me down. We still want to do a lot of business together, don't we?
You mean that's all you had me come out here for?
Yes  siree -- that's the idea. Get them all here and then say: "Look, folks -- here's Daniel Webster, my guest of honor." Golly, I can see their eyes pop already.
You want me to go around --
You keep that -- that's for you. I want you to talk up the party to make sure that the best folks really come.
You think that's a joke? I had him on there too, but I was afraid Dan'l Webster might feel insulted.
The only one you missed -- is the President.
Now look -- here's a list of the people I invited -- they're all the right kind of people -- or did I miss anybody?
Yes.
Yes -- and that's the reason I wanted to talk with you. You got my invitation?
Dan'l Webster?
Dan'l Webster is coming to my party.
Why of course --
Oh yes -- yes. Won't take a minute. Can you keep a secret?
Well, Jabez -- I'm a little pressed for time. You wanted to discuss something -- some business --
You really think so?
How do you do, Belle? How are you, Jabez?  Well -- mighty elegant house you got here.
Howdy, Squire! Howdy! Oh -- how do you do, Squire.
Well? Don't a politician have to be?
But -- I was just lucky.
Selectman? Selectman of the village? Me?
And so, Jabez Stone, in the name of the Whig Party of Cross Corners, we offer you the nomination of that party for Selectman.
Camomile tea!
Worst I had in years -- ahem -- starting a spring cold, I guess -- er -- don't happen to have a bit of camomile tea in the house, do you, Stone?
Headache -- Squire?
Oh!
Ahem -- Neighbor Stone, we want--
Mighty good of you to come out, Squire -- sparing all this time to --  Sheriff, too -- and Schoolmaster -- mighty nice.
Come right into the parlor, won't you, folks.
Ahem -- we want to have a little confidential talk with you, Neighbor Stone. Don't like to take a man away from his planting -- but sometimes --
Morning, Jabez.
Why -- good morning, Squire.
Shall we?
Coming along, Jabez?
Mary!
Jabez -- Jabez!
All right, Jabez ...
You must go now, Mary -- you must!
Oh, Jabez! ...  Did you hear, Mr. Webster? --  Now you'll help him, won't you?
Mary! Come back ...
Jabez!
Mr. Webster ... Wait! ...  Mary!
What's the matter with 'em? Why don't they come?
It's -- different, Jabez -- that's all.
Think this room is larger than anything Webster's got at Marshfield? You've been there. What about it, Mary?
I don't know, Jabez.
Why don't they come --
Oh, for heaven's sake, leave me alone!
Well -- I am worried about the way you've changed. That was one thing you said you'd never do -- remember?
It shows on your face.
But Jabez, I never said that!

He's my son and I like him the way he is. Why do you always have to pick on him? If it's not the boy it's me. You don't like the way I live -- you don't like my friends, or my new house -- or anything.
My fault? ... Oh, Jabez -- all I want is to be proud of him. He can be such a fine boy, if we show him how to be.
Isn't that your own fault?
Jabez -- how can you let her talk like that when the boy is present? He won't respect me any more.
You're not supposed to punish my son, Mary.
I am going to lock him up.
What happened.... Where are you taking him?
Nothing, Jabez -- just natural for a baby to cry, sometimes.  Shh, little Daniel -- sleep -- sleep --
What in sugar hill's the matter with him?
Potato bug sits on the leaf in the sun, Sleep, sleep, my baby -- Raccoon sits in the spruce all night, Sleep, baby, sleep --
Don't be cross with him, Ma. This don't happen every day.
Well -- I -- I-
Hello, Jabez --  Here's your son.
Mary --
Mary -- but look -- it didn't touch an ear of my corn -- we'll have a rich harvest.
Ruined -- all the fields -- ruined.
I wasn't used to being big -- wasn't used to thinking in big ways. Now, I've made up my mind.
Jabez -- once you said we'd never change --
And I don't want to have a washwoman for a wife.
No, no. I don't want to be idle.
Well -- that's the last time -- we'll have servants to do it.
But Jabez -- the washing has to be done --
But it's not very becoming to you to have your hands in the suds -- when the Squire and his wife --
It's very becoming to you, Mr. Selectman.
I'm serious.
Yes, Mr. Selectman!
That's one thing I want to talk to you about, Mary.
I'll never get my washing done.
You could have knocked me down with a feather -- Selectman -- me.
Oh -- Jabez.
Mary! I'm -- Selectman of Cross Corners!
Thanks, Mary.
I'll get it, Jabez.
Mary, get three cups of camomile tea for the Squire and the rest. They all feel colds coming on.
Jabez --
Mary --
Don't take cold, Jabez.  Come -- it's warm in here.
Yes -- you are right, Mary. I can almost hear the little blades of grass a-starting up -- All the seeds a-stirring underneath the ground --
There's hope and promise in it, Jabez -- Planting and promise of good harvest to come.
Mary -- you just wait and see -- It's all -- just the beginning -- just the beginning -- of everything. I'll be the biggest man in New Hampshire and you'll be the wife of the biggest man.
You'll never change -- will you?
There is nothing to worry about now.
Worried!
Tired?
But I'm glad to be home again --
Oh, Jabez -- it was a wonderful day --

Remember, Mary, how he said it: "Couldn't have done better myself, Jabez Stone," and it was my first speech. I don't know what came into me, Mary. I just stood up and the words came flowing like water out of my mouth.
Yes, Mary.  It's been a long day.
We must go on home, Jabez.
Looks right elegant, Mary.
What do you think of that, Jabez?
I'd love to.
Will you come into town with me tomorrow?
It feels fine now, Jabez.
Mary -- look! Hessian gold. I found it in the barn.
Well -- I -- I don't know -- I would pay our debts and well -- maybe get a new bonnet, but -- really -- I think I would live the same.
Mary -- what would you do?
Jabez!
Mary -- what would you do with a pot o' gold?
No, Jabez -- all I need is some rest -- You go and pay our debt. Everything'll be all right then ... everything.
I'll get the doctor.
Mary -- how do you feel?
Jabez ...
Mary--
You're right, Mary it's a fine calf. That's why Stevens'll take it for the rest of the payment.
Oh Jabez! And we were counting on ...  It's a lovely calf.
Seed alone won't do, Mary. We have to throw the calf in.
Jabez!
I will, Mary -- always thought a man could be stronger alone -- seems I've been wrong about that.
Jabez -- you ought to talk to Tom about joining the Grange.

Mary, I'm a farmer -- always will be. To me seed isn't a thing to pay debts with, it's alive, more alive than anything -- but I guess you're right. We just got to do it. Oh -- how's it all going to end?
You always said, the field uphill needs a rest, but if you think --
To save us work on the spring plowing?
Jabez! Couldn't you take a sack of seed instead?
If the pig hadn't broke his leg, we could have taken him.
It's all right, Jabez. We'll find something to pay Stevens.
Yes -- I had to pay the vet in full. He just wouldn't have treated the horse this time. After all, we can't very well do without a horse.
Not all of it?
Mary -- it's gone.
Do you think I'm grudging it?
Your butter money?
We can still use my butter money.
Well -- what are we going to do?
If it would only move old Miser Stevens -- We've still got to pay him.
That's wonderful language. It would move a stone.

" ... and if the final vote shall leave thousands of our fellow citizens and their families in hopeless distress, can we -- members of the Government -- go to our beds with a clear conscience, can we, without self- reproach, supplicate the Almighty Mercy to forgive us our debts as we forgive our debtors?
It's Tom Sharp and two other fellers -- Oh, glory -- where's my pants?
Who is it?
Well, I'll be -- there's a rig, turning in, by the gate.
Hold the splint tighter -- it's almost done.  Go on reading, Ma. This man, Job, he had troubles, didn't he?
He's stubborn as a Stone.
That's what we said.
Jabez, don't you remember your own wedding? We said it's for better or worse. We said it's for richer or poorer.
I remember Dad used to say sometimes, when they were handing out hard luck, the farmers got there first.
Yep.
Oh, Jabez.
I think his leg is broken.
You're right, Mary.
Now, Jabez! I've got on my Sunday bonnet and I'm going to church with my husband. Almost the first time since the beginning of winter -- and if that isn't an occasion, I don't know what is.
What is that smile on your face?  Is there anything wrong with me?
All right -- only he needn't dirty my pants!
He only wants you to throw the stick for him, Jabez. I guess he's feeling the spring a-coming, too.
Down, Shep! Down!
Coming.
Jabez -- help!
Of course it's all right, son. You had Daniel Webster, didn't ye?  Breakfast's ready!  I've made a special surprise for Mr. Webster.
Ma -- Ma -- it's all right, Ma!
Gone with Daniel Webster -- to Marshfield, son.... You told Mary to go--
Ma! ...  Where's Mary ... and little Dan'l?
My son ... what's the matter?
And I say she won't! I'll not have the scorn of God on this place -- with the smell of fish in it, polluting up the Sabbath!  And as for you -- let me tell you, young woman...!
I want you to fix these fish!
Sure, Ma.
You go down and see what's keeping Dorothy.
Fiddlesticks! She don't hear it. Got better music to listen to than that.  There -- that's what I mean.
Golly, Ma --  Consarn that music! Shouldn't a-had the harvest festival tonight.
You'll be a father any minute now.
Ma -- is she? --

Make out? We'll do better than that!  I never thought I'd be glad for bad luck, but I am. I never thought I'd be glad of a hail storm at harvest time, but I am! Oh, bless ye the works of the Lord in the hail and the storm and the rain!
Now that's the way to talk, Son! I know you worked hard for that crop. But we'll make out.
I say -- it don't matter.
What's that you say, Son?
It don't matter!
Oh, here you are, Jabez. Lan's, I was worried about you.... Hail in August! The crops will be ruined!
A man can always change things, Son. That's what makes him different from barnyard critters.
Ma -- and yet, a man could change that, couldn't he?
You see, son? I'm old and I've lived. When a man gets his money in bad ways -- when he sees the better course and takes the worse -- then the devil is in his heart -- and that fixes him.
Wouldn't profit him none.
I know, Ma, but -- Suppose a man got his money in bad ways --
Why, that's just sense, Son. Now a man like Daniel Webster -- guess they pay him high for what he does. But he's worth it -- and he helps others. Makes all the difference.
Do you really think that?
I figure that depends a mite on how you get it and how you spend it, Son.
Money -- money's a funny thing, ain't it, Ma?
Me -- a son.
